raw_text: Following (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009), stance, as used in this work, refers to an overall position held by a person toward an object, idea or proposition
clean_text: Following (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009), stance, as used in this work, refers to an overall position held by a person toward an object, idea or proposition.

raw_text: Our work is also different from related work in the domain of product debates (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009) in terms of the methodology
clean_text: Our work is also different from related work in the domain of product debates (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009) in terms of the methodology.

raw_text: Some previous research looked at the related field of opinion mining, also on political discussion, as in (AbuJbara et al, 2012), (Anand et al., 2011) or (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009)
clean_text: Some previous research looked at the related field of opinion mining, also on political discussion, as in (AbuJbara et al, 2012), (Anand et al., 2011) or (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009).

raw_text: pro or contra (like those of (Walker et al, 2012) or (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009) are not applicable in our case
clean_text: As we aim at performing a finegrained analysis, approaches merely classifying pro or contra (like those of (Walker et al, 2012) or (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009) are not applicable in our case.

citing_paper_authors: Clint, Burfoot | Steven, Bird | Timothy, Baldwin
raw_text: Somasundaran et al provides another argument for the usefulness of collective classification (specifically ICA), in this case as applied at a dialogue act level and relying on a complex system of annotations for link information. Somasundaran and Wiebe (2009) propose an unsupervised method for classifying the stance of each contribution to an on line debate concerning the mer its of competing products
clean_text: Somasundaran and Wiebe (2009) propose an unsupervised method for classifying the stance of each contribution to an on line debate concerning the merits of competing products.

citing_paper_authors: Pradeep, Dasigi | Mona, Diab | Amjad, Abu-Jbara | Dragomir R., Radev
raw_text: Somasundaran and Wiebe (2009) presents an unsupervised opinion analysis method for debate-side classification
clean_text: Somasundaran and Wiebe (2009) presents an unsupervised opinion analysis method for debate-side classification.

raw_text: There have been some related works that focus on discovering the general topics and ideological perspectives in on line discussions (Ahmed and Xing, 2010), placing users in support/oppose camps (Agarwal et al, 2003), and classifying user stances (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009)
clean_text: There have been some related works that focus on discovering the general topics and ideological perspectives in online discussions (Ahmed and Xing, 2010), placing users in support/oppose camps (Agarwal et al, 2003), and classifying user stances (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2009).

raw_text: Stances in on line debates: Somasundaran and Wiebe (2009), Thomas et al (2006), Bansal et al (2008), Burfoot et al (2011), and Anand et al (2011) proposed methods to recognize stances in on line debates

citing_paper_authors: Alexander, Conrad | Janyce, Wiebe | Rebecca, Hwa
raw_text: However, most research into subjectivity has focused on sentiment with respect to concrete things such as product debates (e.g., (SomasundaranandWiebe, 2009), (Yu et al, 2011)) and movie re views (e.g., (He et al, 2011), (Maas et al, 2011), (Pang and Lee, 2004))
